text: teresa thank you very much for this
invitation in looking back at my time as
the world bankruptcy I oh I don't think
I ever could have envisioned this day
especially not speaking to 7500 people
on a panel with so many fabulous women
so it is an honor and a privilege to be
here many of you have heard of the World
Bank but many of you don't know what we
actually do we are not a bank in the
very traditional sense of the word we
don't give people mortgages we don't
home consumer checking accounts rather
we're an organization that was founded
at the end of the Second World War and
like many other UN organizations we were
founded by treaty but our mission was
very special our mission was to rebuild
Europe and Japan we originally had 23
member countries today 71 years later we
have a hundred and eighty-nine member
countries and like the evolution of our
shareholder base our mission has moved
as well the end of the mid-1970s we had
all but reconstructed Europe and Japan
and so we pivoted our organization to
look at the poorer countries and today
we are one of the largest sources of
assistance to countries who support the
poorest of the poor and we do that
through five subsidiaries working with
both the public and the private sector
so I was excited to become the world
bankruptcy I oh but when I took the job
I realized the organization had spent
the better part of the last ten years
not investing in technology nothing
really worked well everything was kind
of bubble gum did shoestring together to
give you a sense we had a 17 year old
on-premise heavily customized email
system and the worst part about it was
we weren't helping those end users those
World Bank Group staff who live
in and travel to some of the most
difficult and hard to reach countries on
earth just last year alone our staff
made 250,000 trips oftentimes the
country was where connectivity is
extremely poor this came honestly too
light for me about six months into my
time as the world bankruptcy I oh I went
to Mongolia to speak at a young leaders
conference and when I travel like that I
tend to drop into our country offices
just to see how the eyeties really
functioning and a young testing leader a
new ambattur said to me Stephanie would
you like to see our modern operations
portal in action and I said well yeah
sure show me how it works so she booted
up the application we went to lunch she
came back and it was still loading the
800 fields of data from our feet our
systems of record in Washington DC and
that's when I said to myself we have a
really serious problem and we need to
change the way we give our staff
information in a novel and innovative
way we needed to make it available
anytime anywhere and from any device now
about the same time the current
president of the world bank Jim Kim
became the president and he came into
the bank with two really audacious goals
the first was to alleviate poverty by
2030 that means making sure that no one
in the world lives on less than a dollar
twenty five a day the second audacious
goal was to create shared prosperity and
by shared prosperity he meant taking the
bottom forty percent in any country and
continuing to lift them up so they never
fall back into abject poverty so I said
to Jim this is really great these are
wonderful audacious goals we're never
going to get there with the technology
that we have today we need modern
technology and technology that's fit for
purpose now luckily for me Jim is a bit
of a techie himself he understood what I
was asking for and he gave us the green
light to go ahead
so my team and I sat down and we created
a very detailed very innovative strategy
tied very closely to those twin goals
but when we took a step back we said to
ourselves this is incredible vision but
without the right implementation plan
we're never going to make this a reality
so we've spent the last three and a half
years executing on that plan we have
ripped out and upgraded almost every
single application and platform in the
bank and we've completely changed the
technology landscape so think back to
that task team leader in Mongolia how
could it be that we could give her the
data that she needed anytime anywhere
from any device and how could we make
sure that she didn't have to dial back
through a tiny little wire to ADC
centric heavily customised application
answering those questions required us to
rethink the connectivity we provided to
our country offices the devices we were
giving our staff the applications we
were developing and maintaining the data
centers we had and perhaps most
importantly how could we use the cloud
and we really knew we needed to create a
renaissance NIT at the World Bank Group
but having a cloud first strategy and
having cloud first as a pillar in that
strategy was not easy remember when we
started four years ago there were
neither no other UN organizations in the
cloud there were no multilateral banks
working in the cloud and even worse
there were no commercial banks or
investment banks doing anything in the
cloud so when I went to our senior
management and said we really need to
move to the bank to the cloud it was met
with quite a lot of skepticism fact one
of the lawyers said to me well Stephanie
that would be like taking every bit of
confidential information the world bank
group had packing it into a cardboard
box writing free on it and putting it on
the curb
and I said well it's not quite like that
it's it's a little different so we got
to the crux of the matter and the crux
of the matter really is about protecting
our privileges and immunities so I said
at the beginning we were created by
treaty and what that allows us is that
our files and our vaults are
impenetrable by local law enforcement
you cannot subpoena the World Bank Group
for information so when I started
talking about taking our data outside of
our data center outside of our firewall
our lawyers got a little uneasy what we
were required to do was actually work
with outside counsel and slowly but
surely we put together a legal frame
that our lawyers got comfortable with
our business was excited about it and we
were ready to begin to innovate
technology in the bank in a way that we
hadn't seen since we'd since we
connected our country offices globally
first we moved our email we had when we
started a hundred and eighty-six servers
in a hundred and eighty-six country
offices hosting our email to me that
attack surfaces was more dangerous than
putting our email in the cloud we also
had a substantial amount of adopted but
unsanctioned use of cloud applications
primarily for file sync and share
because if you go back to those two
hundred and fifty thousand trips that
our staff were taking they wanted to be
effective and efficient wherever they
were in the world and so they were using
tools that they found that were helpful
to them so we became one of the very
first NGO like organizations to adopt a
file sync and share a corporate
off-the-shelf file sync and share and it
was Matt with such enthusiasm that today
we're adding about three terabytes of
data to that platform a week and we're
now looking at the platform saying what
else could it do for us besides file
sync and share so for those of you who
haven't moved to the cloud yet you're
probably thinking a bit daunting file
sync and share email I remember when I
took my job as the CIO someone said to
me
there are two ways to lose your job as a
CIO one is to have a security breach and
the second is to change people's emails
but I'm here to tell you that was the
easy stuff it truly was the low-hanging
fruit and now that we've gotten into the
cloud with AWS and some of our other
partners we're doing fabulous things
think back to that monolithic
application great big in a data center
in washington d.c we're now taking all
of those applications and ripping them
apart and building very very small
single purpose applications powered by
microservices we're re architecting all
of our applications and de-linking the
end user experience from the system of
record in washington DC again making
them faster and more efficient for our
staff in the field we're giving our
economist's in the cloud on demand
massive compute power this is allowing
them to take datasets very disparate and
large data sets geospatial datasets
sensor data ships mobile phone data and
mash it together in ways we never
thought possible to help us do one thing
find better development solutions and
we're doing all of this for the end user
in mind knowing that they can go
seamlessly from a PC to a tablet and to
a phone in essence what we're building
is a brand-new world bank group all 250
of our major applications will be
securely placed in the cloud and we have
found that working in the AWS
environment has done many things for us
it's given us access to security tools
we never had it's allowing us to use
containerization probably most
importantly what it's giving us is
access to state-of-the-art applications
that would have been too complex to
bring into our environment and to
replace what we already had so you've
heard me talk a bit about the cloud and
you're getting the idea that our
original idea save money become more
agile secure our data these are all
things that we've found possible in the
cloud but there were a couple of things
that we didn't seem we didn't see coming
the first learning came to us in
Afghanistan so we have a compound in
Afghanistan we hold 125 of our staff and
the compound in Kabul shortly after we
gave people file sync and share in the
cloud and email in the cloud we needed
to evacuate our team from Kabul and take
them to a city in the north where he we
had never operated before luckily for us
our country director had said to all of
those staff he used these new tools
instead of or in lieu of using those
shared drives in the office at the same
time we had started to play with some
cloud-based unified communication tools
and we were able to take 125 of those
staff from Kabul to the north and in 24
hours they were fully functional you'll
remember in april of last year nepal was
hit with an earthquake 7.9 magnitude i
happened to be in northern india at the
time and we were hearing of casualties
building collapses in other chaos only a
few days before that earthquake my
technology team again had started to
play with some unified communication
tools in the cloud and within hours we
were able to ensure that our staff and
their families were safe and as soon as
we could provide backup generation once
again they had access to their emails
and their files from wherever they were
in nepal very similarly in Burundi in
May of last year there was a military
coup and all of the UN agencies had to
evacuate their staff immediately now in
a situation like this I would have had
to have said to my IT coordinator go
back to the office pull our servers
physically take them on the airplane
we're flying everyone to Nairobi
reinstall those servers in our office in
Nairobi this might have taken a week two
weeks before we actually had our staff
up and functional in this case in
Burundi we wiped the servers remotely we
made sure everybody left the country
with a mobile device we had offices for
them in the Nairobi office and they were
ready to work within 24 hours so for us
the cloud has brought some very
unexpected been
fits as well so as an IT leader of 1,200
people I never would have believed that
the cloud would have created the
creative energy and drive for change
that it has at the world bank group
today when I meet staff as opposed to
when I started they talked to me about
how excited they are about the cloud and
particularly AWS because it's helping us
solve backup and storage and disaster
recovery but it's also helping us figure
out how we can get better citizen
feedback for the countries that were
working on with our projects and now
that we're in the cloud I wouldn't say
we're in the cloud we continue to
innovate we continue to learn and we
continue to experiment but at the same
time the world has seen more natural
disasters in the last few years and
we've seen in decades climate change is
affecting everything that the bank is
doing and the world is experiencing the
largest refugee crisis that we have seen
in modern history these things are
making alleviating poverty that much
more difficult for us and with the world
economy in a very unstable place
actually meeting those twin goals
alleviating poverty and creating shared
prosperity is getting harder and harder
I truly believe having watched our
evolution in the cloud the unexpected
benefits of the cloud will continue to
help us they're going to allow us to
change technology and truly help us find
ways to alleviate poverty by 2030 thank
you
